blocks.text: November 20, 1949 – Trip to Hawk Mountain Sanctuary.
Covered bridge over Maiden Creek between Virginville and Lenhartsburg.

Hawk Mountain is located about 70 miles from Lancaster in the extreme northern section of Berks County, near the Schuylkill County line. It is a massive promontory 1500 feet above sea level, where because of the continuing production of the upward air currents attractive to soaring birds a vantage point, perhaps unique in the world, is secured for the observation of the seasonal flights of hawks and eagles during the months of September and October. A sanctuary association has acquired more than 1400 acres for the birds' protection. Ornithologists from all over the country visit the spot.
Hawk Mountain Entrance

Nancy's birthday, for the first time, falls on Thanksgiving Day. She is ten years old.
Her gifts include a Girl Scout uniform, which she is wearing, and a Donald Duck wrist watch.
We visit our favorite Swiss cheese house on the Lincoln Highway near Gap.
Kathy and Cindy inspect ears of corn in a field south of Strasburg.

blocks.text: December 4, 1949 – a trip to Cornwall via Brickerville; return through Mt. Greta
Just beyond Brickerville we cross the new Pennsylvania Turnpike, now under construction from Carlisle to King of Prussia.
At the Lebanon Pumping Station where the first traces of snow are found.
Cornwall suggests a section of Old England.

CORNWALL BANKS
One of world's greatest iron mines. oldest operated continuously in the New World.
It has been mined for more than two centuries, and is still the greatest iron ore deposit in Superior

blocks.text: The old Grubb mansion is now a Methodist Church home. The old red Grubbbb mannssion on mii iiis now a Mettlednodiist C Churcrch hhhmomomomee..
Many castle-like sands stone homes are found in the vicinity.
On the way home, we stop at Mt. Gretna to see the solid block of devastation left by a recent fire.
Cornwall Furnace, built by Peter Grubb, was in continuous operation from 1742 to 1883.
End - trip to Cornwall.

Mid–December – the children engage in a ball game while on a trip to Beverly,
N. J. to visit Uncle Jim Landreth and his family.

blocks.text: Third bridge - over Octoraro Creek on a dirt road just north of Route 472, probably rarely seen by others than local farmers.

These three bridges in the same general area were previously photographed on other trips.
Left - covered bridge over W. Branch Octoraro Creek at Kings Bridge.
Left, below - bridge over Octaroro at Pine Grove just below, site of Chester reservoir in process of completion.
Right, below - bridge over W. Branch Octoraro to the rear of Chester reservoir, which may be covered by water when reservoir is filled.

blocks.text: Approaching Weirton, W. Va.
Inn Colliumnnumbbbbuis, DDick A Andes standsbefore before his new office.
"Time out", as we pass through Washington Court House, Ohio from Columbus to Cincinnati.

We arrive in Cincinnati and immediately cross the Ohio River for this across-the-river view of Cincinnati.from Covington, Ky. The suspension bridge was completed in 1867 by John A. Roebling, of Brooklyn Bridge fame. In Cincinnati has grown up the greatest machine-tool-making trade in all history. This was Gordon and Kitty's first trip to Kentucky, the only state east of the Mississippi River never before visited.

blocks.text: Fort Zeller, one of the earliest outposts against the Indians, near Womelsdorf.
Right and below; in mid-April we entertain Cisi Huiber and John Eshelman prior to their wedding... with Ve and Bill.

On April 20, 1950, Louise while playing alone ran a knife into her left eye. She spent twelve days in the General Hospital and an operation was performed by Dr. Fulton. There will be permanent impairment of the sight in the eye.
May 8, 1950 – a visit to the Capitol of Pennsylvania at Harrisburg. Shown are Kathy, Uncle Tom, and Cindy.

blocks.text: Our children, assisted by a group of neighbors, give Corky a bath in the back yard.
Nancy - early May.

STREET ROAD
Pennsylvania authorized in 1815 a state road from Middle Ferry Bridge (Market Street), Philadelphia to McCall's Ferry Bridge on the Susquehanna. This road was called Street Road. It derived its name from William Penn, and referred to as Street Road during the Revolution. The road surveyors reached McCall's Ferry while Burr was building his famous bridge.
McCALL'S FERRY AND BURR'S BRIDGE

blocks.text: May 9 to 14, 1950 – Gordon and Harold Reece, representing Educators Mutual Insurance Company, drive to Boston, Mass. to attend the Conference of the Insurance Accounting and Statistical Association.

FIRST DAY, May 9, 1950 – Left Lancaster 1:15 P. M; to Paoli, to Norristown, to New Hope, to Morristown, to New York via Geo. Washington Bridge, to Merritt Pkwy., in Connecticut, to a point near Milford where we spent the night.
Gordon set to go.
Lunch near Coatesville.

SECOND DAY, May 10, 1950 - (rain all day) along the Connecticut coast to too Narragansett, R. I., north to Providence, east to Plymouth, north along the South Shore to Boston. Headquarters at the Statler in Boston.

Guilford Conn., first settled in 1639 by colonists from New Haven, is one of the most beautifully preserved old villages in southern Conn. A score or more homes date from the l8th century, many of them bearing the date and the original owners name at the doorway.
Whitfield House (much restored), supposedly the oldest stone house in New England.
"Saltbox" house in Guilford, built in 1761.

blocks.text: Groton- New London Bridge built in 1943 at a cost of $6 million is l/8 mi. long with a clearance of 135' above the Thames River.

Conn., founded in 1654, is an old shipbuilding and shipping center.
Here we found the 100 yr. old whaler, "Chas. W. Morgan" at dock.
Wickford, R. I., on Narragansett Bay, is an historic old town with many fine, well-preserved homes.

blocks.text: Plymouthouth, in spite of tourists, is still a busy fishing town.

National Monument to the Forefathers, erected in 1888, is said to be the largest granite monument in the world (note Harold at base). It rises 81' above the hill. Main figure on pedestal is Faith; at base are seated figures representing Morality, Law, Education and Freedom.
Two of the oldest houses in Plymouth: (left) the William Harlow house, built in 1649; (right) the Howland house, built in 1667. Both apparently much restored.

blocks.text: Colorful Gloucester harbor, on picturesque Cape Ann, is today still one of the great fishing towns of the East coast.

SATURDAY, MAY 13, 1950 - we begin the return trip from Boston by heading west across northern Massachusetts, visiting Lexington, Concord, the industrial towns of Fitchburg, Gardner and Athol, through Greenfield, where the Mohawk Trail begins, to a spot beyond the little village of Charlemont. Rain caught up with us again at Greenfield.

Lexington, where on April 19, 1775 was fired "the shot heard around the world", the curtain-raiser to the American Revolution, when American farmers at the Village Green refused to disperse at the order of General Gage's troops who were advancing to Concord to destroy supplies which were supposed to be collected there.
Church on the Green.

blocks.text: The Connecticut River, 360 miles long, is the longest river in New England. It rises at the Canadian border, divides New Hampshire and Vermont, flows through Massachusetts, and then through Connecticut to Long Island Sound. It drops some 1,600 feet enroute and provides the water power for industry in many New England cities.
Lofty, graceful French King Bridge over the Connecticut River, with the river valley spread out far below.

SUNDAY, MAY 14, 1950 - (clear) into the Berk-shires, south to Great Barrington, west across the Hudson River to the Catskillskills, through the mountains to Hancock, across the Delaware Riv- er, through the coal regions, and home.
Saturday night at these cabins along the Deer-field River. So cold the next morning our fingers became numb...ice on windshield wipers.
Left – from the Hoosac range of mountains we gaze down on North Adams, with the Berkshires in the background. We had breakfast and filled the tank with gas at North Adams.

blocks.text: Trip to Boston - continued
Mt. Greylock, 3,491 feet, highest point in Massachusetts.

Just west of North Adams, we begin the more than eight miles climb to the top of the mountain. Since the road is not yet open for the spring season, we do not pass a car or see a single person on the whole trip. We do spy a porcupine disappearing into the underbrush at the side of the road. For the descent, we take the mountain road which leads south in the direction of Pittsfield.

blocks.text: Trip to Boston - continued.

At Haines Falls we reverse our route to secure this magnificent view of the Hudson River Valley from cliff edge at Catskill Mountain House, a view said "to compare with any in the United States". Catskill Mountain House is fast becoming a deserted ruin, although an attendant did charge us 30¢ each for the view.
End - trip to Boston.
Louise, Kathy, Carolyn Wilhelm, Kitty and Grandmother Landreth.
Visitors from Johnstown - Jay and Betty Demi.

blocks.text: A brief respite from the rain as we head south for Harmon and the high mountains.
Despite the rainfall, we drive to the top of Bickle Knob, 4,000 ft., to find only clouds and mist which obscure all views.
In a downpour of rain we reach Elkins and spend the night at these new, luxurious cabins. Here, in the morning, the storm clouds are drifting away.
South from Elkins in the Tygart Valley...then southeast across the mountains. Note our road far behind us in the valley.
Across Cheat Mountain, 3,802 feet, and Shaver Mountain, 3,760 feet. We are in Monongahela National Forest.

blocks.text: Durbin is a typical valley community along the Greenbrier River. The air is cool and invigorating.
Just before we descend to Germany Valley, we pass the Birthplace of Rivers. The sign tells why the region is so named.

On a gravel road, which leaves much to be desired, we climb Spruce Knob, 4,860 feet, highest point in West Virginia. The road runs within half mile of the fire tower at top. Due to dampness, we content ourselves with views from roadway.

blocks.text: Just before reaching Franklin, we turn north along the South Branch of the Potomac River, and with the River we enter the Smoke Hole region, a valley completely hemmed in by high, steep mountains. Until twenty years or so no road entered this valley and the people have continued to live here in a manner little different than they did before the Revolutionary War. The region has long been famous for its bootleg whiskey. During the severe floods of a year ago the whole region was almost washed out. Hugh boulders have been washed down the side of the mountain and in places it has been necessary to rebuild the entire road. We lookeded in vain for one particularly rustic cabin in a gulch which apperently was washed away without trace.
Hugh rocks have been blasted to provide a roadway into the Smoke Hole.

blocks.text: A good spot for making a steak over a charcoal fire in the Smoke Hole.

Rocky cliffs line the road near Petersburg, W. Va.
Here we stopped to watch a baptismal by complete immersion in the river, which was accompanied by much singing of hymns. We were unable to get close enough for a picture.
Kitty secures a drink of water from a road-side bubbler as we head northward....and home.
A river goes psychopathetic and seeks escape under a mountain, to reappear two miles distant.
